when a director knows how to start a movie
description:
David Fincher is a master of storytelling, and Fight Club might be his most immersive film. Even among classics like Se7en, Zodiac, and The Social Network, its opening sequence stands out. A fast-paced montage that pulls you into the Narratorâ€™s world while seamlessly delivering exposition. In this video essay, I break down how Fincher uses editing, visuals, and pacing to hook the audience from the very first frame. With unforgettable performances by Edward Norton, Brad Pitt, and Helena Bonham Carter, Fight Club remains one of the most influential films in modern cinema.

title: Der grÃ¤sslichste Matthias-SchweighÃ¶fer-Film aller Zeiten!
description:
Es war zuletzt etwas ruhig um Matthias SchweighÃ¶fer geworden, wohl auch, weil er seine Karriere in Hollywood ankurbeln wollte. Nun ist er mit â€Das Leben der WÃ¼nscheâ€œ zurÃ¼ck im deutschen Kino und legt damit den furchtbarsten Film seiner langen Karriere vor. Keine romantische KomÃ¶die, keine BlÃ¶deleien, nein, dieser Film will tiefsinnig und philosophisch sein. Es findet sich jedoch weder einen originellen Gedanken noch ein interessantes Bildâ€“ das allein macht diesen Film aber noch nicht zu etwas Besonderem. Bemerkenswert hingegen ist, dass hier der Versuch unternommen wird, aus dem Status quo auszubrechen. SchweighÃ¶fer spielt einen Mann mit schÃ¼tterem Haar und Eheproblemen, der aus dem Alltagstrott aussteigen kann, weil ein wundersamer Herr ihm so viele WÃ¼nsche gewÃ¤hrt, wie er nur mÃ¶chte. Was wÃ¼nscht man sich, wenn alles mÃ¶glich ist? Der Film ist ein Offenbarungseid: Wir sehen hier paradigmatisch, wie die Irgendwas-mit-Medien-Millennials nichts anzubieten haben. Die Matthias-SchweighÃ¶fer-Pro7-Generation ist vÃ¶llig blank. Mehr dazu von Wolfgang M. Schmitt in der Filmanalyse!

title: How this scene takes Pulp Fiction from good to masterpiece
description:
The first 500 people to use my link will get a 1 month free trial of Skillshare: https://skl.sh/lancelloti08241

In this video, we dissect one of Pulp Fiction's most iconic scenes: the tense apartment confrontation with Jules (Samuel L. Jackson), Vincent (John Travolta), and Brett (Frank Whaley). We'll delve into how Quentin Tarantinoâ€™s masterful direction, the unforgettable performances by Jackson and Travolta, and the scene's sharp dialogue come together to create a cinematic classic. Discover how this moment of high tension and dark humor has cemented itself as a standout in film history. Whether you're a Tarantino fan or simply curious about the art of crafting unforgettable scenes, this breakdown is for you! Editing, filmaking, cinematography, and more.

description:

In this video I outline the five key elements of film and how they can be used to analyse any film. title: un film dâ€™animation bouleversant sur la difficultÃ© des personnes dyslexiques
description:
Ce film d'animation s'inspire d'un fait vÃ©cu, il raconte le combat d'un enfant dyslexique, un combat permanent contre les mots, les livres, les prÃ©jugÃ©s, les moqueries et le systÃ¨me Ã©ducatif.

Un combat qui le fait se sentir seul et dÃ©semparÃ© face Ã  cette difficultÃ© qu'il imagine comme une montagne Ã  gravir.

Un jeune enfant dyslexique tombe dans un monde entiÃ¨rement fait de livres. Seul dans cet environnement, il est forcÃ© d'escalader une montagne reprÃ©sentant le systÃ¨me Ã©ducatif.

Le court mÃ©trage d'animation Â« Je suis dyslexique Â» exprime ce que l'on ressent lorsqu'on a une maniÃ¨re diffÃ©rente d'apprendre dans le systÃ¨me scolaire actuel. Ceux qui apprennent diffÃ©remment devraient Ãªtre fiers de qui ils sont et ne devraient jamais Ãªtre amenÃ©s Ã  se sentir seuls. Le film utilise des mÃ©taphores fortes pour dÃ©peindre ces Ã©motions, nous suivons un jeune garÃ§on dans son voyage oÃ¹ il escalade une montagne dans un monde fait de livres.

Â« Je suis dyslexique Â» : est un court mÃ©trage d'animation dirigÃ© par un Ã©tudiant, produit et Ã©crit par Mads Johan Ã˜gaard et Jatie Wyman. Nous sommes dyslexiques et avons expÃ©rimentÃ© diffÃ©remment la maniÃ¨re dont le systÃ¨me scolaire tente de gÃ©rer les Ã©tudiants dyslexiques, les bonnes et les mauvaises. Nous avons fait ce film dans l'espoir de donner aux individus qui vivent l'apprentissage diffÃ©remment, une chose Ã  laquelle se comparer, se rapporter.
Quelque chose pour dire : " Oui, c'est un voyage difficile, mais tu n'es pas seul et tu peux surmonter les Ã©preuves ! ". C'est un message fort avec lequel beaucoup d'entre nous n'ont pas grandi. C'est pourquoi nous voulons que ce film soit vu le plus possible , dans l'espoir qu'il donne aux personnes en difficultÃ© le courage de persÃ©vÃ©rer.

title: Was 22 BAHNEN mit dem Neoliberalismus zu tun hat: Kritik & Analyse
description:

Die Geschichte von Tilda, das Mathematik-Talent aus prekÃ¤ren VerhÃ¤ltnissen, steht ununterbrochen in den Charts. Die Verfilmung bleibt eng an der literarischen Vorlage: Tilda (Luna Wedler) lebt mit ihrer 11-jÃ¤hrigen Schwester Ida in der Provinz, wÃ¤hrend ihre MitschÃ¼ler nach dem Abitur nach Berlin aufgebrochen sind. Ihnen nachzufolgen ist nicht leicht, da Tildas Mutter trinkt und zu cholerischen AusbrÃ¼chen neigt. Ida will die Schwester eigentlich nicht allein lassen. Ãœberdies lastet ein traumatisches Ereignis noch immer auf Tilda. Nur im Schwimmbad, wenn sie dort ihre 22 Bahnen schwimmt, hat sie Ruhe und ist ganz bei sich. Ordnung und Struktur gibt ihr das Schwimmen, wo doch sonst laufend das Chaos droht. Die Geschichte erscheint vÃ¶llig unpolitisch, aber eben darin liegt auch eine politische Botschaft. ğŸ¬ WELCOME TO THE INSIDERS FILM SCHOOL
This series teaches you how to analyse film, one concept at a time. Each episode breaks down a key idea in film studies, giving you the tools to understand and write about film with confidence.

THIS EPISODE: How to Analyse Performance
In this lesson, we explore performance in filmâ€”the art of acting and how it creates meaning on screen. Youâ€™ll learn a clear three-step framework for performance analysis:
1. Casting â€“ what the choice of actor communicates before they even speak.
2. Styles of Acting â€“ from classical acting to method acting and everything in between.
3. Performance Codes â€“ the details of voice, face, body, and interaction that shape our reading of a character.

Weâ€™ll use a range of examples, from The Joker to The Godfather, to show how actors transform scripts into unforgettable performances. Whether youâ€™re preparing a film studies essay, revising for exams, or just want to understand how to analyse acting in film, this video gives you the tools you need.

Plus, youâ€™ll get a masterpiece film assignment at the end to sharpen your skills.

title: Soyez prÃªt pour savoir si ...  #film #thanos #marvel #mcu #infinitywar #endgame #analyse
Analyze That: Mobster Mayhem Returns #movie #actor  #classiccomedy #robertdeniro
description:
Analyze That (2002) is the sequel to the hit comedy Analyze This. Directed by Harold Ramis, the film follows mob boss Paul Vitti (Robert De Niro) as he is released from prison and placed under the custody of his reluctant psychiatrist, Dr. Ben Sobel (Billy Crystal). Struggling to adjust to life outside the mob, Vitti hilariously attempts normal jobs while being drawn back into his old world of crime. Packed with sharp humor and the comedic chemistry of De Niro and Crystal, Analyze That delivers a fun follow-up to the original film.

title: How to Analyse Editing | Insiders Film School
description:
WATCH THE WHOLE SERIES HERE:
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLsfW5NgYbnPKs6BZypAy71-Ttnmt3aFhD
â¸»
SUPPORT THE CHANNEL TO ACCESS EXCLUSIVE CONTENT AND THE DISCORD COMMUNITY!
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCGXfqzVEZr0XaZLWG3_HniA/join
http://www.patreon.com/themediainsider
â¸»
THIS EPISODE: How to Analyse Editing

In this lesson, we dig into one of the most powerful â€” and often invisible â€” tools in filmmaking: editing. Youâ€™ll learn how meaning is created between shots, and why the cut is the single most important device in film language.

We trace editing from its origins in early cinema â€” when filmmakers first discovered they could interrupt a shot â€” through the breakthroughs of pioneers like George Albert Smith and Edwin S. Porter, all the way to the conceptual leap known as the Kuleshov Effect. By the end, youâ€™ll understand why every edit is a decision that shapes how we read a scene.

Youâ€™ll explore the two major approaches to editing:
1. Continuity Editing â€” match-on-action, eyeline match, shot/reverse shot, crosscutting, the 180 and 30 degree rules, and the use of establishing shots to create seamless, intuitive storytelling.
2. Expressive Editing â€” jump cuts, smash cuts, montage, and techniques that deliberately draw attention to the cut to make meaning through contrast, rhythm, and juxtaposition.

Weâ€™ll also look closely at cutting tempo, and how the rhythm of editing can build tension, heighten emotion, or shift the energy of a scene â€” from fast-paced chaos to slow, suffocating stillness. And finally, weâ€™ll talk about the rare but powerful continuous shot, where filmmakers remove the cut entirely for maximum impact.

Youâ€™ll finish with a clear, practical framework for applying all of this to your own analysis using the Three Ts: Tone, Tempo, Technique â€” perfect for essays, exams, and sharpening your critical eye.
â¸»

12:57 Cutting tempo

title: THE GODFATHER PART 2 (1974) MOVIE REACTION - Al Pacino | Robert De Niro| Crime Saga Classic
description:
I KNOW IT WAS YOU, FREDO!!  The Godfather Part II Full Movie Reaction Watch Along: https://www.patreon.com/thereelrejects
- The Godfather Part III (1990) Movie Reaction: https://youtu.be/vYFMHLuND20
- THE GODFATHER (1972) Movie Reaction: https://youtu.be/aBfhnaQ0Wg4
- Gift Someone (Or Yourself) An RR Tee!  https://shorturl.a
Having finally seen the OG, Coy & Aaron are BACK to continue the quintessential Cinematic Crime Saga, giving their Godfather 2 Reaction, Breakdown, Recap, Analysis, Commentary & Spoiler Review! 

Coy Jandreau & Aaron Alexander react to The Godfather Part II (1974), Francis Ford Coppolaâ€™s landmark crime drama sequel that expands the Corleone saga into an operatic meditation on power, legacy, and moral decay. Widely regarded as one of the greatest sequelsâ€”and filmsâ€”ever made, Part II deepens the tragedy of the Corleone family while mirroring past and present in devastating fashion.
The film intercuts two parallel narratives: the ruthless consolidation of power by Michael Corleone (Al Pacino â€“ Scarface, Dog Day Afternoon) in the late 1950s, and the immigrant rise of his father Vito Corleone, portrayed by Robert De Niro (Taxi Driver, Raging Bull) in a career-defining performance. As Michael tightens his grip on the family empire, paranoia and betrayal corrode his relationships, particularly with Kay Adams-Corleone (Diane Keaton â€“ Annie Hall, Somethingâ€™s Gotta Give) and his brother Fredo (John Cazale â€“ The Deer Hunter, Dog Day Afternoon). Meanwhile, young Vitoâ€™s journey from Ellis Island to the streets of New York reveals the roots of the Corleone myth and the choices that shaped it.
The legendary ensemble elevates every frame, including Robert Duvall (Apocalypse Now, Tender Mercies) as loyal consigliere Tom Hagen, Lee Strasberg (Network) as calculating rival Hyman Roth, Talia Shire (Rocky, Creed) as Connie Corleone, and Michael V. Gazzo (The Panic in Needle Park) as volatile informant Frank Pentangeli. Iconic and highly searched moments include Vitoâ€™s arrival at Ellis Island, the assassination attempts in Havana, Michaelâ€™s chilling Senate testimony, the flashback to Vitoâ€™s first act of vengeance, and the unforgettable climax on Lake Tahoe that seals Michaelâ€™s transformation forever.
With Gordon Willisâ€™s shadow-drenched cinematography, Nino Rotaâ€™s haunting score, and Coppolaâ€™s masterful parallel storytelling, The Godfather Part II stands as a profound exploration of family, ambition, and the isolating cost of absolute powerâ€”an epic sequel that redefines what cinema can achieve.
#TheGodfatherPartII #TheGodfather2 #FrancisFordCoppola #AlPacino #RobertDeNiro #CrimeDrama #ClassicCinema #MobMovie #CorleoneFamily #FilmHistory #MovieReaction #FilmReview #Classics #ClassicMovies #React #ReactTo #Reaction #FilmStudies

title: Comment faire un film d'animation : le processus avec leevea.fr
description:
CrÃ©er un film d'animation est un processus complexe qui implique plusieurs Ã©tapes, allant de la conception initiale Ã  la production finale. Voici un guide gÃ©nÃ©ral pour t'aider Ã  comprendre les Ã©tapes principales :

1. DÃ©veloppement de l'idÃ©e
Concept : Commence par dÃ©finir l'idÃ©e de base de ton film. Quelles sont l'histoire, le message ou les thÃ¨mes que tu veux explorer ?
ScÃ©nario : Ã‰cris un scÃ©nario dÃ©taillÃ© qui dÃ©crit les dialogues, les actions, et les scÃ¨nes du film. Un bon scÃ©nario est la colonne vertÃ©brale de tout film d'animation.
Storyboard : CrÃ©e un storyboard, un ensemble de croquis qui illustrent les scÃ¨nes clÃ©s du film. Cela t'aidera Ã  visualiser la mise en scÃ¨ne et le flux narratif.
2. Conception des personnages et de l'environnement
Design de personnages : Dessine et modÃ©lise les personnages principaux et secondaires. Pense Ã  leur apparence, leur style, et leurs caractÃ©ristiques distinctives.
CrÃ©ation des dÃ©cors : ConÃ§ois les dÃ©cors oÃ¹ se dÃ©roulera l'action. Cela peut inclure des paysages, des bÃ¢timents, et des objets que les personnages utiliseront.
3. PrÃ©-production
Animatique : Un animatique est une version simplifiÃ©e du film qui utilise les images du storyboard en sÃ©quence, avec des dialogues et une musique temporaire. Cela permet de voir comment le film se dÃ©roulera dans le temps.
ModÃ©lisation 3D (pour l'animation 3D) : CrÃ©e des modÃ¨les 3D des personnages, des objets, et des dÃ©cors si tu choisis de faire une animation en 3D.
Rigs et Squelettes : Pour les personnages 3D, crÃ©e des rigs (squelettes numÃ©riques) qui permettront de les animer.
4. Production
Animation : C'est l'Ã©tape oÃ¹ les personnages sont animÃ©s. En fonction du type d'animation (2D, 3D, stop-motion), tu devras soit dessiner image par image, soit manipuler des modÃ¨les 3D.
Animation des dÃ©cors : Les dÃ©cors peuvent Ã©galement Ãªtre animÃ©s, surtout si le film comprend des Ã©lÃ©ments interactifs ou en mouvement.
Effets SpÃ©ciaux : Ajoute des effets visuels pour enrichir l'animation, comme les explosions, la fumÃ©e, ou les reflets lumineux.
5. Post-production
Montage : Assemble toutes les scÃ¨nes animÃ©es en une sÃ©quence cohÃ©rente. Le montage final inclura les transitions, le timing, et le rythme du film.
Son : Enregistre les dialogues, ajoute les effets sonores, et intÃ¨gre la bande-son. Le son est crucial pour crÃ©er l'ambiance et renforcer les Ã©motions.
Rendu (pour l'animation 3D) : Rends les images 3D dans leur qualitÃ© finale. Cela peut Ãªtre un processus long, car chaque image doit Ãªtre calculÃ©e avec des textures, des lumiÃ¨res, et des ombres.
6. Distribution
Promotion : PrÃ©pare une stratÃ©gie de promotion pour ton film. Cela peut inclure des bandes-annonces, des affiches, et des campagnes sur les rÃ©seaux sociaux.
Projection : Organise des projections de ton film dans des festivals, des salles de cinÃ©ma, ou en ligne via des plateformes de streaming.

description:

How to Analyse Editing | Complete Beginners Guide

http://www.patreon.com/themediainsider
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
ğŸ¬ WELCOME TO THE INSIDERS FILM SCHOOL
This series teaches you how to analyse film, one concept at a time. Each episode breaks down a key idea in film studies, giving you the tools to understand and write about film with confidence.

THIS EPISODE: How to Analyse Cinematography
In this lesson, we step behind the camera to explore cinematography â€” the art of how films are shot and framed. Youâ€™ll learn a clear three-step framework for cinematography analysis:
1. Camera Position â€“ shot types and angles, from extreme wides to close ups.
2. Composition â€“ how framing tools like symmetry, the rule of thirds, and leading lines create meaning.
3. Camera Movement â€“ pans, tracks, dollies, cranes, handheld shots and more, and how they shape our experience of a scene.

Weâ€™ll look at how cinematography can lean towards realism (like the handheld urgency of Children of Men) or formalism (like the symbolic choreography of an upside-down shot), and how these choices impact our interpretation. Whether youâ€™re preparing a film studies essay, revising for exams, or just want to understand how to analyse cinematography, this video gives you the language and tools you need.

Plus, youâ€™ll get a masterpiece film assignment at the end to sharpen your skills â€” this time, The Revenant.
â¸»
â±ï¸ TIMESTAMPS
00:00 Intro
01:38 What is cinematography?
03:26 Camera position
06:32 Composition
09:13 Camera movement
12:30 Realism vs Formalism
15:29 Masterpiece assignment

title: connais-tu vraiment le cinÃ©ma d'animation ? #cinema #animation #quiz #2danimation
JOURNÃ‰E INTERNATIONALE DU CINÃ‰MA D'ANIMATION
Pourquoi c'est le plus beau film d'animation.
description:
L'animation a beaucoup Ã©voluÃ© ces derniÃ¨res dÃ©cennies. Disney, Pixar, ou encore le Studio Ghibli au cinÃ©ma, pendant que la Toei Animation ou Sunrise (Bandai Namco Filmworks) sorte les dÃ©sormais classiques One Piece, Dragon Ball ou CowBoy Bebop (oui, je pourrais faire une liste infinie mais non, je n'ai pas envie de m'embarquer la dedans). La technique et les technologies avanÃ§ant, cette animation est devenue toujours plus belle, fluide, rapide, rÃ©aliste, comme un course effrÃ©nÃ©e Ã  la frame cachÃ©e au milieu d'un combat que l'on pourrait encadrer (note: ne pas faire ca pour Fight Club). 

Mais du coup, c'est quoi une belle animation ? Et c'est laquelle, la plus belle de toute ? 

Et si on se posait ensemble pour parler du conte de la Princesse Kaguya, de Isao Takahata, de son histoire, de l'idÃ©e Ã  sa sortie en passant par le processus de production, pour finalement se demande si ca n'est pas cette animation, la plus belle de toute?   

Tu me paies un petit cafÃ© ? https://www.buymeacoffee.com/Pandapple 

Les jours raccourcissent, prenez le temps de vous voir raconter des histoires, car comme dirait un fameux groupe, c'est bon bon, c'est bon pour le moral. 

Antoine.

title: THE SHINING (1980) Breakdown | Ending Explained, Easter Eggs, Creepy Hidden Details & Film Analysis
description:
THE SHINING (1980) Breakdown | Ending Explained, Easter Eggs, Creepy Hidden Details & Film Analysis, Making Of Things You Missed. In this video, we are gonna break down an all-time classic movie which is The Shining. There are hidden details, easter eggs, creepy subliminal images and lots of things Stanley Kubrick put in the movie to mess with your mind. We will be going through all the details within the movie that make this such a good film and point out all the easter eggs that make this so chilling and mind-bending. There are so many hidden layers to the film and throughout this video, we're gonna be breaking down all the subliminal ways that the movie messes with you along with its hidden meanings. Starring Jack Nicholson in one of his most iconic performances in this Stephen King novel adaption from director Stanley Kubrick, this is often credited as one of the best horror movies ever made. I am very excited to analyse it, now let's journey together to the Overlook Hotel.

#TheShining #TheShiningEndingExplained #TheShiningBreakdown #StanleyKubrick #JackNicholson #Horror #Redrum #TheOverlookHotel #room237 #EasterEggs #EndingExplained #hiddendetails #ClassicMovieBreakdown #StephenKing #ThingsYouMissed #TheShiningThingsYouMissed #TheShiningHiddenDetails

If you enjoyed this video then please subscribe to the channel https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCq3hT5JPPKy87JGbDls_5BQ?sub_confirmation=1

Facebook - https://www.facebook.com/DeffinitionMC/

Follow our team at - 
Host & Editor Paul - https://twitter.com/heavyspoilers
Host & Editor MT - https://twitter.com/MasterTainment
Host Greg - https://twitter.com/TheGregAlba
Editor Steesh - https://twitter.com/SteeshHaggie
Editor Matt - https://twitter.com/SuperHeroNexus



/* ----- VIDEO INFORMATION ----- */


Ok so the Shining is one of my favourite movies of all time. Depending on what day it is the top spot for me switches between this, the thing and the godfather. It's one of those movies that has stuck with me since the first time I watched it and I remember being about 8 years old scared out of my mind after my first visit to the overlook hotel. But why does it have this long lasting power and influence. I mean on the surface you could be forgiven for thinking that the movie is extremely simple. As a kid I thought it was pretty much just about a family who were given the job of looking after a hotel and the dad went crazy and tried to kill them. However there's so many hidden layers to the film and throughout this video we're gonna be breaking down all the subliminal ways that the movie messes with you along with it's hidden meanings.

Now the biggest head f**k is the hotel itself.

King came up with the idea for The Shining when visiting The Stanley Hotel out in Boulder Colorado. He and his wife booked it October 30th which was the night before it was just about to close for the season. They were the only two guests there and King spent the night wandering the long hallways of the hotel swept up in just how creepy a place like this could be if it wasn't teaming with guests.

Now the idea of Shining comes from the John Lennon song Instant Karma.

-

This idea that people imprinted into something long after they're gone is what the Overlook embodies and it's seemingly filled with the souls of those that it's trapped along the way. Traumatic events leave longer lasting impressions and this is why it's teaming with all sorts of evil spirits.

title: This is how a film breaks the rules ğŸ¥ğŸš In Adolescence, simple tracking shot turns into a flying shot
description:
This is how a film breaks the rules. In Adolescence, simple tracking shot turns into a flying shot. The camera locks onto a drone and takes off, creating a seamless moment that feels impossible. Itâ€™s a perfect example of modern filmmaking pushing the limits of what we expect on screen.

#Adolescence is a British drama starring #StephenGraham and #OwenCooper, who both recently won Emmys for their work on the series. It follows the fallout of a crime committed by young Jamie, highlighting the impact of social media influence on young, vulnerable people. The series was acclaimed for its gritty realism, intuitive camerawork and visceral acting performances.

title: Shoojit Sircar recommends his favourite films by contemporary filmmakers
6 Ways to Edit Any Scene â€” Essential Film & Video Editing Techniques Explained [Shot List Ep. 10]
description:
Ultimate guide to film and video editing techniques, including eyeline match, cross cutting, eye trace, j cut and l cut, intellectual montage, and cut on action.

Ultimate Guide: Editing Techniques â–ºâ–º https://bit.ly/sl-ed
View Editing Techniques Storyboards â–ºâ–º https://bit.ly/et-stb
What is a Jump Cut? â–ºâ–º https://bit.ly/wh-jc
StudioBinder Blog â–ºâ–º http://bit.ly/sb-bl

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€

Chapters:
00:00 - Intro â€” Editing: Creative Uses of the Cut
01:32 - Walter Murch & The Rule of Six
02:46 - Eyeline Match
05:55 - Cross Cutting
07:57 - Eye Trace
10:13 - Split Edit
13:14 - Intellectual Montage
15:40 - Cut on Action
17:54 - Honorable Mentions and FREE Reference Shot List

â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€

Film editing is a language that started with the simple cut over a century ago. Since then, film and video editing techniques have turned that language into poetry. In this episode of The Shot List, weâ€™re looking at the major film editing and video editing techniques that can be used when editing a scene. These techniques include eyeline match, cross cutting, eye trace, split edits, intellectual montage, and cut on action. Weâ€™ll explain how to edit video using these techniques and what they bring to the storytelling process.

First up is the eyeline match â€” where a characterâ€™s eyes guide the edit. If we see a character notice something off-screen, our immediate response is â€œWhat are they looking at?â€ Most of the time, the editor complies and cuts to match the characterâ€™s eyeline (not only what they see but from their literal or general perspective).

In film editing, cross cutting (or intercutting) is essentially weaving two or more scenes into one. The classic example of cross cutting is the baptism scene in The Godfather as we watch Michael become â€œThe Godfatherâ€ twice over â€” to his sisterâ€™s child and to the Corleone family as we watch his men assassinate his rivals.

One bit of film theory from legendary editor Walter Murch is called eye trace. To help the viewer along, eye trace suggests to cut between shots when the area of focus is in the same spot. That way, the viewer can stay focused on the moment, especially when rapidly cutting through action scenes.

A hard cut is when both the sound and image are switch simultaneously to the next shot. But a split edit allows for the sound or image to switch before the other. These are known as either the J cut or the L cut â€” based on the way they look in a film editing timeline. These techniques are useful in dialogue scenes to help pace out the conversation and allow for reaction shots.

Intellectual montage is a fascinating bit of editing theory that suggests that when presented with two images back-to-back, the viewer will search for a connection between them. When deployed strategically, filmmakers can create meaning through juxtaposition that wouldnâ€™t otherwise be there. 

And, finally, much of movie editing is built around the cut on action â€” when a cut is made within a character or objectâ€™s movement in the frame. Rather than creating a chaotic onslaught of fragmented punches and kicks, the cut on action creates a more seamless flow.

These are the essential film editing and video editing techniques that editors use all the time. And as soon as you master these video editing tips and tricks, youâ€™ll be able to speak that language fluently.

Le cinÃ©ma est censÃ© Ãªtre l'art visuel le plus influent et le plus persuasif qui peut, de maniÃ¨re simple et involontaire, transformer le public d'un Ã©tat psychique Ã  un autre. Cela veut dire qu'il peut diriger les spectateurs involontairement vers une certaine croyance ou une certaine conduite. Pour analyser un film, il faut faire une brÃ¨ve prÃ©sentation du documentaire:
